awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Improving Capabilities of Micro-scale Vibratory Systems by Embracing and Accounting for Large-Amplitude Responses
awd_abstract_narration:
This project considers the development of techniques to assist in the design and optimization of micro-electro-mechanical-systems (MEMS) that utilize resonant vibrations.   These micro-scale devices are important elements in many consumer electronics and products including wireless telephones, automobiles, and entertainment devices. The capabilities of these systems are often limited by a number of factors that restrict their range of operation, such as their maximum amplitude of vibration.  This research pursues a fundamental understanding of these limitations and developing systematic tools for improving the performance of these devices.  The broader impact of this project includes outreach, mentoring and training, inclusion of students from underrepresented groups, development of classroom materials motivated by the research, and dissemination of results.  This project will result in multidisciplinary training of students, who benefit from the close collaboration and integrated theoretical and experimental research approach of the PIs.   Also, the PIs and their graduate students will continue their longstanding participation in summer outreach programs to middle- and high-school students, and the inclusion of undergraduate research assistants. The PIs also plan to create an alumni mentoring program for graduate students, in which current graduate students will be connected with alumni who will offer professional advice and support.

Most commercial devices that employ vibratory MEMS are designed so that the resonant elements operate in their linear range and the designer can rely on simple models to analyze their response.  However, this sets limits on their operating range that do not take full advantage of their potential.  There have been recent efforts demonstrating significantly improved performance when nonlinear effects are systematically included in the MEMS design process.  The focus of this project is to embrace nonlinear behavior in resonators, to develop an understanding of the attendant limits, and to develop and experimentally demonstrate design methods that allow one to optimize performance in this realm.  The research focus is on MEMS that operate with one or two fundamental vibratory modes that can be described by weakly nonlinear models so that analytical methods, namely perturbation techniques, and the theory of normal forms, are applicable.  These models are linked with multi-physics computational tools and optimization techniques, using normal forms to formulate objective functions for the applications of interest.  Devices developed with these tools will be fabricated, characterized, and tested to validate the approach.  Applications will include frequency generation, frequency conversion, and inertial sensing.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to develop techniques for improving the performance of micro-scale vibrating systems such as those used in modern sensors and time-keeping devices.  This research is part of an overarching drive towards enhancing the functionality of these systems, which are used in all smart phones, computers, automobiles, and elsewhere.  Current designs of these tiny electro-mechanical structures are based on their well-understood (small amplitude) linear response, but a thorough understanding of their nonlinear (large amplitude) behavior has the potential to significantly enhance their operation.  The focus of this work is to use physics-based models and mathematical tools to predict system dynamic response and use that knowledge to design devices that can operate effectively in their nonlinear regime.  These analytical studies are complemented by experimental work carried out by collaborators.  This represents a new line of research in which one uses optimization methods to improve the nonlinear dynamic response of vibrating systems.   

The intellectual merit outcomes include fundamental contributions about vibrating systems and results directly relevant to practical devices.  In terms of fundamental work, we used shape optimization methods to demonstrate how one can tailor the nonlinear response of vibrating systems to extend their linear dynamic range, thereby improving their signal characteristics.  A sample image from this work is shown in Figure 1 which depicts three microbeams with different geometries and their attendant computer models.  These simple, systematic alterations significantly changed the beam vibration characteristics and resulted in an increase of its linear operational vibration amplitude.  Specifically, the beam shown in the middle has nearly twice the operating range as the uniform beam show on the top.  These tools were the first to combine shape optimization with nonlinear vibration response and can be applied to a wide class of structural systems.

In terms of sensor applications, we considered a model of a vibratory rate gyroscope used for measuring rotation rates, for example, in automotive stability systems.  A physics-based model for ring-shaped gyros with segmented electrodes, as shown in Figure 2 along with its two important vibration modes, was developed and studied using analytical and computational tools.  By manipulating the gyro shape and the voltages on the electrodes it is predicted that one can tailor the vibration response of the system and significantly increase its output signal.  This represents another example of optimizing nonlinear vibration response for practical purposes.

Our investigations also considered methods of reducing the effects of noise in these systems.  The most significant results were in two categories.  The first topic considered a model for predicting the frequency stability of self-oscillating systems, such as those used for signal processing in smart phones.  Our work demonstrated that one can use large amplitude signals with a special operating point to reduce frequency fluctuations of the oscillator.  The curves in Figure 3 represent a measure of the frequency fluctuations (smaller is better) versus operating amplitude for six different tuning arrangements.  The sharp dips shown at large amplitudes allow one to take advantage of a large signal that does not amplify the noise, as compared with the blue curve, which represents typical operating conditions.  This scheme offers significant potential for improving the precision of the microscale time-keeping devices used in communications.  The second topic relates to the use of parametric pumping, that is, the periodic modulation of system stiffness, to alter the resonant frequency characteristics of microsystems.  We developed a theoretical model that accurately predicts how one can alter the noisy signal characteristics and these results were experimentally validated.  Figure 4 shows a schematic of one of the tested devices (top left), the effects of the parametric pump amplitude on the frequency spectrum (bottom left), and the effects of parametric pump frequency on the frequency spectrum (three panels on the right).  The curves in the bottom two panels are from the theory and the data are from experiments, showing excellent agreement.

In terms of broader impacts, the project trained several students in multi-disciplinary subjects in engineering and physics, as required to design micro-electro-mechanical systems.  Of the four students who earned MS degrees in Mechanical Engineering, two are women, including one Latina.  Also, outreach programs to middle school and high school students were conducted in which the optimization of dynamic systems was demonstrated using hands-on projects involving structural dynamics.  In addition, the research results of this project were disseminated by publications in technical journals, a patent, and presentations at conferences and seminars.  The PI and his collaborators have close ties with microsystem companies so that the results of our research were made readily available to relevant industrial contacts.
